title: Virtual or Physical Soroban? I Bought a Real One for $15 – Now It's Collecting Dust
description: I thought a physical abacus was essential. Turns out the app version works just as well – maybe better. Here's my honest comparison.
imageAlt: Comparing physical Soroban abacus with digital app version

content.intro: When we started Soroban, I immediately ordered a physical abacus from Amazon. $15, wooden beads, looked authentic. Three months later? It sits on a shelf collecting dust while my son uses the app version every day.

sections.text: Why I Thought Physical Was Better
Tactile learning, right? Kids learn better when they touch things. That's what I read. Made sense to me.
Plus, staring at screens all day is bad. A physical tool felt more "wholesome."
The physical abacus was great for the first week. My son liked sliding the beads. But then...

items: No feedback – he didn't know if his answers were right
No progression – just the same beads, no levels or rewards
Easy to lose pieces – beads came loose
Hard to carry – couldn't practice anywhere

sections.text: The app version? Instant feedback, game-like progression, always available on his tablet. He just gravitated toward it.

items: Very young kids (4-5) who need tactile stimulation
Kids with limited screen time rules
Competition training (official Soroban tests use physical)
Initial introduction to understand how beads work

sections.text: My recommendation: Start with the app. If your child takes to it and wants to compete or you want to limit screens, then get a physical abacus.
I don't regret buying the physical abacus. It helped in the beginning to understand what we were getting into. But I learned that for daily practice, the app wins.
Don't feel pressured to buy physical equipment right away. Most kids do just fine with app-based learning, and you can always add a physical abacus later.

faq.question: Will my child miss out by only using the app?
faq.answer: No. The goal of Soroban is mental math (Anzan) – eventually doing calculations in your head without ANY abacus. The app teaches this just as well, with better tracking.

faq.question: Should I buy a physical abacus at all?
faq.answer: If you want, it's a nice supplement – especially for young kids or for variety. But it's not required. Many successful Soroban learners train primarily on apps.

cta.text: Start with the app version and see how your child responds. No equipment needed.
